Item.Title: Early Lisberger Studios Animation
Item.Description: Using conventional animation, Lisberger produced the following animated logo for his studio, which was licensed as advertising to several readio stations around the country. This was the first appearance of a character that he called Tron.

Item.Title: "Computers are People Too"
Item.Description: Originally Aired in May 1982, "Computers are People Too" presented a look at the (then) current state-of-the-art in computer graphics. That program includes a sneak preview of Tron, which was to be released in theaters in August of that same year. Following is the Trong segment of the program, which includes interviews with writer/director Steven Lisberger and co-supervisor of special effects Richard Taylor.

Item.Title: Early Video Tests
Item.Description: Uncertain that the proposed special-effects techniques would work on film, The Walt Disney Studios commissioned Steven Lisberger to create a short test reel. The thirty-second film was shot in both the Vistavision and 35 MM anamorphic formats using actors dressed in light grey costumes against white backgrounds.

Item.Title: "Beyond Tron"
Item.Description: The following is an excerpt from a TV special entitled "Beyond Tron," which explores Magi's involvement in Tron.

Item.Title: NATO
Item.Description: After finishing the live-action photography for Tron, the filmmakers assembled a five-minute sample reel to be shown at the National Association of Theater Owners (NATO) convention. This reel, which took about six weeks to produce, served as a trial run for the visual effects procedures to be used in the post-production work.

Item.Title: Work-In-Progress
Item.Description: The following is a work-in-progress trailer. It is of particular interest to note that it contains original black and white production footage (with production audio), as well as early tests for computer animation.

Item.Title: Deleted Scenes Introduction by Writer-Director Steven Lisberger
Tron and Yori's Love Scene
Item.Description: The so-called "Love Scene" between Tron and Yori features some of the most extensive backlight compositing in the film. Over forty separate elements were generated to create the final composited background of Yori's "Transformed" apartment. This scene was deleted so late that it has its complete effects animation, as well as full score and sound effects.

Item.Title: Tron and Yori's Love Scene #2
Item.Description: A second scene in Yori's quarters (commonly referred to by the filmmakers as the "Morning After" scene) was also deleted from the film. This scene was originally intended to follow Flynn's journey in the recognizer. Audio tracks for this scene do not exists.

Item.Title: Alternate Opening Prologue
Item.Description: In order to clarify the interaction of the electronic world and the real world of Tron, an opening prologue (consisting of three paragraphs of text) was added to the film. This prologue was included on the international english language release prints and subsequent domestic prints for the film's wide release in the United States.

Item.Title: Design Introduction by Writer-Director Steven Lisberger
Creation of Tron Main Title-Moebius Storyboards
Storyboard-To-Film Comparison Introduction by Storyboard Artist / Animator Bill Kroyer
End credits with original Carlos music
Item.Description: Only a segment of Wendy Carlos' end credit music is featured in the final-release version of Tron. The second half of her end credit score was replaced by the song "Only Solutions," contributred by the rock group, Journey. The following clip represents Wendy Carlos' original end credit music in its entirety.

Item.Title: Lightcycle scene with alternate Carlos music tracks
Item.Description: The music for Tron was composed by Wendy Carlos. In two instances, the composer's original music was deleted from the final version of the film. Following is a reconstruction of the lightcycle sequence with its original musical underscore. Carlos had originally composed an electronic score to accompany the lightcyle sequence. This music was not used in the final version of the film. The final soundtrack features only the character dialogue and the sound effects of the lightcycles.

Item.Title: Lightcyles: Syd Mead discusses lightscyle design
Recognizer: Space Paranoids Video Game - Letterbox
Item.Description: The footage originallhy created by Magi as a full-frame image, but was later stretched to widescreen to accommodate the close-up.
